Problem:
Consider a linear system where the displacement vector \\( x(t) \\) over time t is governed by the equation \\( \\frac{d}{dt}x(t) = Mx(t) \\), where M is a constant matrix. We examine the effect of a Fourier transformation \\( F(x) \\) defined by the function \\( F(x(t)) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty x(t)e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\), on the system behavior.

If \\( F(x) \\) is applied to a vector \\( x_0 \\) at t = 0, and then the system evolves under \\( \\frac{d}{dt}x(t) = Mx(t) \\) without further intervention, will the spectral properties of \\( x(t) \\) at t = T reflect the original dynamics governed solely by M?
Explanation: The Fourier transformation changes the domain of the representation from time to frequency, potentially altering the observable characteristics such as dominant frequencies and their amplitudes. This transformation does not preserve the time-domain behavior of the system under M alone.
